messages.content: Hi (:flower) I'm <PERSON>. I'm here to listen without judgment. How are things going with your relationship lately?
I've been with my boyfriend <PERSON> for one year, and sometimes I feel he doesn't understand me (:sad).
That sounds frustrating. Feeling misunderstood in a relationship can be painful. Can you give an example of when you felt that way?
Yesterday, <DATE>, I told him I was stressed about work, and he just said "don't worry" and went back to his phone. (:sad)
It must have felt dismissive. Sometimes partners don’t realize how their responses impact us. What would have felt supportive in that moment?
I wish he had asked more, like "Do you want to talk about it?" or hugged me.
That’s very understandable. Physical comfort and showing interest can make a big difference. Have you tried telling him exactly what you need in these situations?
A little. I said it last month, but he forgets easily. I even sent him a WhatsApp on <DATE> reminding him, using my old phone <PHONE_NUMBER>.
Reminders are normal, especially if someone isn't used to noticing emotional cues. How did he react to the message?
He replied "okay (:sweat_smile)", which didn't really feel like acknowledgment.
I see. That can feel invalidating. Sometimes it helps to discuss these things in person when tone and body language are clear.
True. Also, my friend <PERSON> suggested we try couple’s exercises from this website <URL>.
That could be helpful! Structured exercises can give both partners tools to communicate better. Which exercises seemed most interesting to you?
One is about sharing feelings daily for 5 minutes. Another is writing gratitude notes to each other.
Both sound great. Small consistent practices can strengthen understanding and connection. Would you like tips on introducing these exercises gently to him?
Yes, please.
You could say, "I read about a small exercise to help couples connect better. Would you try it with me for 5 minutes a day?" Framing it as a shared activity can make it less intimidating.
Ok, I can do that. Also, sometimes I overthink texts. Like last week I sent "Are you okay?" and he didn't reply for 3 hours. (:sad)
That delay can feel worrying. Anxiety around messaging is common. Remember, his delayed reply often isn’t a reflection on you, but his own schedule or distractions.
Yeah, I also remember he was distracted when I called him on <DATE>. He was at work.
Context matters. Work can pull attention away. It's natural to want focus, but understanding circumstances can ease tension.
I guess, also, I sometimes get jealous when he talks to his friend <PERSON> too much.
Jealousy often signals a need for reassurance or connection. What would help you feel secure in those moments?
Maybe if he shares small updates or includes me in his plans sometimes.
That makes sense. Communication and small gestures can build trust. Have you shared this with him?
I tried last month, but it ended in a small fight. I feel guilty now.
Conflicts are natural when discussing emotions. What matters is that you’re trying to communicate. Reflecting on what worked and what didn’t can help improve future discussions.
